title: Quiz 4: January 2015 Licensure Exam
description: Complete licensure examination covering Education, Management, Research, and Mental Health from January 2015. Contains all MCQs, Short Answer, and Essay concepts.

questions.question: Role play is an effective means of developing:

options.text: Acting skills which can be used after college

questions.explanation: Role play allows learners to practice communication and interpersonal interactions in a safe, simulated environment, making it ideal for developing these soft skills.
questions.hint: It helps you practice talking to people.

questions.question: A teaching strategy that is best used for linking of theory to practice is:
questions.explanation: Concept mapping visually organizes knowledge, showing relationships between theoretical concepts (pathophysiology) and clinical practice (interventions).

questions.question: The uppermost level in the cognitive domain (Bloom's Taxonomy) is:
questions.explanation: In the original Bloom's Taxonomy, Evaluation is the highest level of cognitive processing.

questions.question: Examples of audio teaching aids include:
questions.explanation: Option D contains only audio formats. Slides and transparencies are visual.

questions.question: The main purpose of clinical instruction is:

options.text: Task mastery and professional identity mentoring
Professional identity mentoring and student fulfillment

questions.explanation: It aims to master skills (tasks) and socialize students into the nursing role (identity).
questions.hint: Learning to do the job and be a nurse.

questions.question: A theory that is based on non-linear approaches of change is:
questions.explanation: Chaos theory deals with unpredictable, complex, and non-linear systems.

questions.question: In reference to organizational structures 'chain of command' refers to:

options.text: Locations where decisions are made in an organization

questions.explanation: The chain of command is the continuous line of authority extending from top to bottom.

questions.question: When a nurse manager is doing a 'SWOT' analysis, strengths and weaknesses represent assessment of:
questions.explanation: Strengths and Weaknesses are Internal factors; Opportunities and Threats are External.

questions.question: The difference between delegation and assignment is that delegation entails:
questions.explanation: In delegation, the nurse transfers the responsibility to act but remains accountable for the outcome.
questions.hint: You can give away the task, but not the blame.

questions.question: The Pareto's principle, when applied to time management, enables nurse manager to:
questions.explanation: The 80/20 rule (Pareto) is used to prioritize the vital few tasks that yield the most results.

questions.question: Variables that exist in a study and can affect the measurement of study variables and the relationship between these variables are called:
questions.explanation: Extraneous variables are any variables other than the independent variable that might influence the dependent variable.

questions.question: Limitations in a study are:

options.text: Restrictions that may reduce the generalizability of findings

questions.explanation: Limitations are potential weaknesses (often outside researcher control) that restrict how findings can be applied.
questions.hint: Limits to how useful the study is.

questions.question: A primary source of literature is better than a secondary source in that:

options.text: Secondary sources contain a lot of misinterpretations of the primary sources
Interpretation of primary sources is always biased
Secondary sources are always low quality

questions.explanation: Secondary sources interpret original work and may introduce errors or bias; primary sources are the original evidence.
questions.hint: Go to the source to avoid rumors.

questions.question: A hypothesis that is used for statistical testing and interpreting statistical outcomes is called:
questions.explanation: Statistical tests generally test the Null Hypothesis (H0) to see if it can be rejected.

questions.question: Internal validity refers to:

options.text: The extent to which effects detected are a true reflection of reality/intervention
The extent to which findings can be generalized
The extent extraneous variables influence study variables
The extent dependent variables influence independent variables

questions.explanation: Internal validity ensures that the results are due to the independent variable and not confounding factors.
questions.hint: Is the study valid inside itself?

questions.question: Loosening of association often occurs in:
questions.explanation: Loose associations (derailment) are a classic thought disorder symptom of schizophrenia.

questions.question: Body dysmorphic disorder is an example of a:
questions.explanation: Historically classified under Somatoform disorders (physical symptoms suggesting medical condition).

questions.question: The most appropriate therapy for a client who has been diagnosed with acrophobia is:
questions.explanation: Systematic desensitization is the standard behavioral therapy for specific phobias like fear of heights (acrophobia).

questions.question: Atypical neuroleptics produce less extra-pyramidal effects because of their reduced effect on:
questions.explanation: Typical antipsychotics strongly block D2 receptors causing EPS; Atypicals have lower affinity for D2.
questions.hint: The receptor most associated with movement side effects.

questions.question: A nursing intervention for a client diagnosed with conversion disorder resulting in paralysis is:

options.text: Give positive reinforcement for any improvement
Advice patient to rest for many hours
Advice client to apply for sick leave

questions.explanation: Positive reinforcement encourages function without reinforcing the 'sick role' or the symptom itself.
questions.hint: Reward progress, don't focus on the symptom.

questions.question: Match Eugen Bleuler's 4 A's of Schizophrenia with their meanings:

pairs.right: Withdrawal into a private fantasy world

questions.explanation: The fundamental symptoms are Affect, Associations, Ambivalence, and Autism.

questions.question: Identify factors that may increase the risk of developing catatonic schizophrenia:
questions.explanation: Risks include genetics, brain structure issues, trauma, and medical conditions.

questions.question: Differentiate between the following terms:

pairs.right: Ongoing feedback during instruction to improve learning
Final assessment at end of course for grading
Pre-determined questions asked in same order

questions.explanation: Formative is during; Summative is after. Structured is rigid; Unstructured is flexible.

questions.question: Arrange Erikson's first three stages of psychosocial development in chronological order:

items.text: Autonomy vs. Shame and Doubt (Early Childhood)

questions.explanation: Infancy (Trust), Toddlerhood (Autonomy), Preschool (Initiative).

questions.question: Match the ethical term with its definition:

pairs.right: Deliberate fabrication or falsification of data
Exploiting subjects or access for personal gain

questions.explanation: Plagiarism is stealing ideas. Fraud is faking data. Misuse is abusing power.

questions.question: Which of the following are manifestations of Somatization Disorder?

options.text: Multiple physical complaints across organ systems

questions.explanation: Key features: many physical symptoms, no medical cause, seeking many doctors, real distress (not faking). Intentional production is Malingering/Factitious.
questions.hint: Real symptoms, no medical cause, many doctors.

questions.question: Select the key principles of Quality Management:
questions.explanation: QM focuses on the customer, improving processes, involving staff, and using data.
questions.hint: How do you make things better?

questions.question: Arrange the phases of the Strategic Planning Process in order:
questions.explanation: Analyze -> Plan -> Do -> Check.
